text.p: European Union fisheries ministers on Tuesday agreed by majority vote a programme to reduce fishing by up to 30 percent over five years to the end of 2001 in a bid to save endangered stocks, EU officials said.
Britain, which had insisted that the problem of so-called quota hoppers be tackled first, voted against -- as did France, which had called for a 15 percent reduction over three years.
"It's done," an official said, adding the deal frees up hundreds of millions of dollars of aid to restructure Europe's fishing industry.

The EU's executive Commission originally proposed a 40 percent reduction over six years but this was fiercely rejected by EU member states, fearful of the political backlash if poor fishing communities were thrown out of work.

EU governments won greater flexibility in choosing whether to cut fish catches by laying up vessels, or by reducing fishing time at sea -- or a combination of both. Small vessels of less than 10-metres in length will be exempted from the cutbacks.

British Fisheries Minister Tony Baldry earlier reiterated that Britain would not implement any cuts until the vexed question of quota hoppers -- mainly Spanish and Dutch fishermen who buy British fishing licences -- was settled.
Removal of the quota hoppers, who take over a quarter of the British national quota, would virtually end the need for Britain to reduce its fishing fleet during the next five years.
